patterns: What is geocoding
what does geocoding do
responses: It converts address into spatial data and associates the exact geographical coordinates for that address.Address geocoding, or simply geocoding, is the process of taking a text-based description of a location, such as an address or the name of a place, and returning geographic coordinates, frequently latitude/longitude pair, to identify a location on the Earth's surface.

It converts address into spatial data and associates the exact geographical coordinates for that address.Address geocoding, or simply geocoding, is the process of taking a text-based description of a location, such as an address or the name of a place, and returning geographic coordinates, frequently latitude/longitude pair, to identify a location on the Earth's surface.

patterns: What is reverse geocoding
what does reverse geocoding do
responses: when a GPS coordinate is entered the street address is interpolated from a range assigned to the road segment in a reference dataset that the point is nearest to.Reverse geocoding is the process of converting a location as described by geographic coordinates to a human-readable address or place name. It is the opposite of forward geocoding, hence the term reverse.

patterns: What is the digitizing process
What is digitization
responses: Digitizing in GIS is the process of converting geographic data either from a hardcopy or a scanned image into vector data by tracing the features.

patterns: What is Point feature

patterns: What is Line Geomtery?
What is Line in GIS
hours of operation
responses: Lines are used to represent the shape and location of geographic objects, such as street centerlines and streams, too narrow to depict as areas. Lines are also used to represent features that have length but no area, such as contour lines and boundaries.
A line is formed by connecting two data points. A computer reads this line as straight, and renders the line as a vector connecting two x-y coordinates.

patterns: what is Polygon Geometry
What is Polygon in GIS
responses: Polygons are used to represent areas such as the boundary of a city (on a large scale map), lake, or forest.
A polygon is defined as a figure with three or more sides, and lying on one plane.

patterns: What is pixel?
What pixel means?
responses: A pixel is one of the small dots or squares that make up an image on a computer screen. The more pixels there are, the more the image looks real or accurate.

patterns: What is TIFF?
Tag image File Format
responses: Tag Image File Format, abbreviated TIFF or TIF, is a computer file format for storing raster graphics images
TIFF file uses the file extension .tif or .tiff. TIFF is also known for its flexibility and has more features and capabilities than other image file formats.

patterns: Raster Data
Formats of Raster Data
responses: A raster consists of a matrix of cells (or pixels) organized into rows and columns (or a grid) where each cell contains a value representing information, such as temperature.Examples of raster file formats are JPEG, PNG, JIF, MrSID

A raster consists of a matrix of cells (or pixels) organized into rows and columns (or a grid) where each cell contains a value representing information, such as temperature.Examples of raster file formats are JPEG, PNG, JIF, MrSID

patterns: Vector Data
Format of Vector Data
responses: Vectors are composed of discrete geometric locations (x, y values) known as vertices that define the shape of the spatial object. The organization of the vertices determines the type of vector that we are working with: point, line or polygon.Examples of vector file formats are SHP, GDB, GeoJSON,KML

patterns: What are Sliver Polygons
Sliver Polygons
responses: Sliver Polygons are small areas which result from spatial overlays of different GIS layers. Typically, sliver polygons occur if slightly different digitalized areas are spatially intersected.
Polygon slivers can occur during extraction when small, thin polygons are accidentally created through an overlap with existing features.

patterns: What is KML
KML
responses: Keyhole Markup Language is an XML notation for expressing geographic annotation and visualization within two-dimensional maps and three-dimensional Earth browsers.
Keyhole Markup Language (KML) is an XML-based format for storing geographic data and associated content and is an official Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) standard.

patterns: What is GeoJSON
Is GeoJSON a JSON
responses: GeoJSON is an open standard format designed for representing simple geographical features, along with their non-spatial attributes. It is based on the JSON format. The features include points, line strings, polygons, and multi-part collections of these types.
GeoJSON is a text-based format written in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) that is sometimes used for interchange of vector data, drawings.

patterns: How can we validate a fire risk model using Monte carlo simulation
I am working on forest fire risk of emission where we used static variables of interest In GIS (slope , climate, vegetation, fire intensity) fire frequency is included in the model
How to use Monte Carlo simulation in ArcGIS or any software to validate the Model
responses: The very basic idea of Monte Carlo simulation is to use a random number generator of a certain statistical model and with a specified set of parameters that belong to this model

The very basic idea of Monte Carlo simulation is to use a random number generator of a certain statistical model and with a specified set of parameters that belong to this model. As such, you need your variables either one by one or in combination and set their values and compute your output (can easily be done in MATLAB), then you export the output to your GIS software.

patterns: Which machine learning algorithm is suitable for remote sensing (time series) explanation
I want to work on satellite images on 16 days basis on a particular area then draw the difference among the pixel values and views those results on the time series explanation.
responses: Cellular automata algorithms are working with pixels natively. You just map pixels from your pictures into a lattice of given size. Each pixel represe to a channel where a time series occur. It is possible to measure the evolution of the whole regions.It would be advisable to use the complexity measures based on entropy as is described in our paper on prediction of ventricular & Torsades de Pointes arrhythmia. This paper is made as a methodology one. Can be applied in your field to.
Prediction of the evolution is based on applying of AI methods (SVM, logistic regression, batching, etc.)

patterns: How does ArcGIS pro handle the different coordinate systems on the same map
Does ArcGIS is making all the needed conversions automatically to project all the features on the map correctly
responses: One of the great convenience features of ArcGIS (both Pro and Desktop) is that they project-on-the-fly, meaning that they perform automatic real-time reprojection of your data.

Yes and no. One of the great convenience features of ArcGIS (both Pro and Desktop) is that they project-on-the-fly, meaning that they perform automatic real-time reprojection of your data. Once a projection is assigned to the dataframe (either by adding the first data layer or by manually setting a projection), any subsequent layer that is added is displayed in that projection. In that sense, the answer to your question is yes. There are a couple of important caveats because the real-time projection is not perfect. In some cases, the layers won't line up exactly on the screen. I think this usually happens when the layers are not just in a different projection, but also have a different datum. You will usually only notice this if the two layers have common features, and you zoom in very close (the error will typically be sub-meter). Because of these minor discrepancies, there are a few best practices:1) Never edit a layer that is in a different projection than the dataframe (you should get a warning if you try to do this),2)Never use layers that are in different projections as clip features (or similar editing and geoprocessing tasks) for each other,3)Don't rely on spatial calculations (e.g. area) on layers that aren't in the current projection,4)By the same logic as #3, ArcGIS will let you take measurements and do calculations on unprojected data (GCS coordinate system), but these will almost always have substantial errors. This is true even if the dataframe is set to a GCS coordinate system as the projection

patterns: What is API RP 581
API RP 581
responses: It is a risk based inspection and it is measured quantitatively based on pipeline history and condition

It is a risk based inspection and it is measured quantitatively based on pipeline history and condition.It will help the pipe line operators to predict the pipeline condition And helping them in predicting risk based on (Risk of failure = Probability of failure * consequence of failure). Probability of failures may happen with any of the following.1)Incorrect operation,2)External corrosion,3)Internal corrosion,4)Threat,5)Pipe defects like crack, dent etc. Based on history, pipeline operators will give the ranking to the failing causes and assess the pipeline condition and mitigation plans will be prepared based on several inputs.

patterns: How to perform a soft ArcGIS Desktop reset
What is a soft rest for ArcGIS Desktop
Do customizations get removed when performing a soft reset
Why are ESRI folders renamed
Renaming ESRI Folders
responses:
Issues related to application profile failure and applications crashing can occur in ArcGIS Desktop if the registry entry is corrupted. Performing a soft reset resolves the issue by closing applications and clearing data in the RAM, in contrast to a hard reset, where user data are removed, and the device is restored to its factory settings.
Read more

patterns: Do customizations get removed when performing a soft reset
How  to recover connections, styles and templates from an archived application data folder
normal.mxt
responses:
Renaming the Esri Application Data folder removes any custom styles, interface customizations, and connections that are stored within the user profile.
To recover ArcCatalog folder connections:
1.Browse to the old ArcCatalog folder and copy the ArcCatalog.gx file.
2.Browse to the new ArcCatalog folder and paste the ArcCatalog.gx file.
3.Click Yes to replace the file.
Recover custom symbols that were created in ArcMap:
1.Browse to the old ArcMap folder and copy the â€˜.styleâ€™ files.
2.Browse to the new ArcMap folder and paste these files into it.

patterns: What is annotation?
How is annotation better than labels
Why should one use annotation over labels
responses:
Annotation allows one with an option for creating and storing map text. An advantage of using annotation as map text over dynamic labels is that annotation can be selected and moved, and its properties can be managed as individual elements. One can create annotations individually and also convert labels to annotation.
Read more

patterns: What is geodatabase annotation
What is geodatabase annotation
responses:
Geodatabase annotation is stored outside the map document as a geodatabase feature class just like geographic features.
Geodatabase annotation can be added to a map as a layer in the table of contents. One can turn it on and off like any other layer.
Geodatabase annotation properties are stored as attributes in an attribute table. The text as well as the annotation attributes such as various values, including symbology, font, and size can be stored.
Related Information

If you are calculating into a text field, you can choose to add a units abbreviation to the calculation.
For instance, 47.5673 sq m is an example of the output of area calculated into a text field with the units abbreviation.
You would need to create a text field in the attribute table.

patterns: Unable to update items in a shared update group in ArcGIS Online
Shared update groups in ArcGIS Online
responses:
Groups that allow group members to update all items in the group are called shared update groups.
At this time, shared update groups are intended for updating item details and the contents of maps, apps, and scenes. Some updates are reserved for the item owner or administrator (such as moving, sharing, or deleting an item and changing ownership).
However, members of this group also have elevated privileges, such as the ability to edit the contents of hosted feature layers, alter editor tracking settings, enable or disable attachments, and alter the layer's schema.
Therefore, proceed with caution when adding members to this type of group.
Currently, most ArcGIS apps do not support updating items shared with a shared update group. To determine whether this capability is supported in a specific ArcGIS app, refer to its product documentation.

Only the owner (or administrator) of the item can perform the following actions on the item (not all actions apply to all item types): delete, share, move, change owner, change delete protection, publish, register an app, overwrite data in hosted feature layers, and manage tiles in hosted tile layers.

Groups that allow group members to update all items in the group are called shared update groups.
At this time, shared update groups are intended for updating item details and the contents of maps, apps, and scenes. Some updates are reserved for the item owner or administrator (such as moving, sharing, or deleting an item and changing ownership).
However, members of this group also have elevated privileges, such as the ability to edit the contents of hosted feature layers, alter editor tracking settings, enable or disable attachments, and alter the layer's schema.
Therefore, proceed with caution when adding members to this type of group.
Currently, most ArcGIS apps do not support updating items shared with a shared update group. To determine whether this capability is supported in a specific ArcGIS app, refer to its product documentation.

Only the owner (or administrator) of the item can perform the following actions on the item (not all actions apply to all item types): delete, share, move, change owner, change delete protection, publish, register an app, overwrite data in hosted feature layers, and manage tiles in hosted tile layers.

patterns: How to capture android traffic using fiddler for monitoring ESRI field apps
Capturing fiddler traffic with Field Maps
Fiddler
responses:
Open Fiddler and select Tools -> Options
Choose the Connections tab
Select the Allow remote computers to connect checkbox to enable the setting
Restart Fiddler in order the changes to take effect
Fiddler is now listening on port 8888 (this is the default port, you can change it from the setting above).
Once Fiddler is listening, we should use it as a proxy in Android.
Open the WiFi menu.
Tap and hold on your current network to show the network details
Choose the Manage network settings option
Check Show advanced options checkbox
Choose Manual from the Proxy dropdown list
Type your IP address in the Proxy host name field
NOTE: You can check your IP address by hovering over the Network Connection icon in the Fiddler toolbar.
Type the Fiddler listening port (8888 by default) in the Proxy port field
Click Save to apply changes.

Read more

Open Fiddler and select Tools -> Options
Choose the Connections tab
Select the Allow remote computers to connect checkbox to enable the setting
Restart Fiddler in order the changes to take effect
Fiddler is now listening on port 8888 (this is the default port, you can change it from the setting above).
Once Fiddler is listening, we should use it as a proxy in Android.
Open the WiFi menu.
Tap and hold on your current network to show the network details
Choose the Manage network settings option
Check Show advanced options checkbox
Choose Manual from the Proxy dropdown list
Type your IP address in the Proxy host name field
NOTE: You can check your IP address by hovering over the Network Connection icon in the Fiddler toolbar.
Type the Fiddler listening port (8888 by default) in the Proxy port field
Click Save to apply changes.

patterns: Can I use Map Viewer Classic when editing a map configured with the Field Maps web app
Using Map viewer Classic
responses:
If you're using ArcGIS Online or ArcGIS Enterprise 10.9.1 or later to configure the map with the Field Maps web app, you can use either Map Viewer Classic or the new Map Viewer when editing the map.
If you're using ArcGIS Enterprise 10.8.1 or 10.9 to configure the map with the Field Maps web app, you must use Map Viewer Beta when editing the map.
If you use Map Viewer Classic to edit the map, the changes you make in the Field Maps web app will be lost.

If you're using ArcGIS Online or ArcGIS Enterprise 10.9.1 or later to configure the map with the Field Maps web app, you can use either Map Viewer Classic or the new Map Viewer when editing the map.
If you're using ArcGIS Enterprise 10.8.1 or 10.9 to configure the map with the Field Maps web app, you must use Map Viewer Beta when editing the map.
If you use Map Viewer Classic to edit the map, the changes you make in the Field Maps web app will be lost.

patterns: Will the forms and feature templates I configure in Field Maps override the symbology, pop-up configurations, and forms that were set up in Map Viewer Classic
Will the forms and feature templates I configure in Field Maps override the symbology, pop-up configurations, and forms that were set up in Map Viewer Classic
responses: If you create a form in the Field Maps web app, it overrides the editable pop-up configured in Map Viewer Classic. The Field Maps web app does not alter symbology or pop-ups.
If you create a form in the Field Maps web app, it overrides the editable pop-up configured in Map Viewer Classic. The Field Maps web app does not alter symbology or pop-ups.

patterns: How do I set up location tracking and authorize ArcGIS Field Maps
set up location tracking and authorize ArcGIS Field Maps
responses:
To use the location tracking capability in ArcGIS Field Maps, location tracking must be enabled for your organization.
To access the location tracking capability in Field Maps, you must purchase and assign an ArcGIS Tracker license to each ArcGIS account that will be tracked. This license is included in the Field Worker user type and is available as an add-on for all other user types (including the Viewer user type).
Read more

To use the location tracking capability in ArcGIS Field Maps, location tracking must be enabled for your organization.
To access the location tracking capability in Field Maps, you must purchase and assign an ArcGIS Tracker license to each ArcGIS account that will be tracked. This license is included in the Field Worker user type and is available as an add-on for all other user types (including the Viewer user type).
Read more

patterns: Do ArcGIS dashboards have support for custom data visualizations and themes
Customizing ArcGIS Dashboard
responses:
Not exactly.The embedded content element can be used to insert visualizations and content not supported out of the box. Further, there are many theme properties that can be controlled via dashboard-level settings. With that said, the Dashboards team is currently gathering requirements around how customers might like to extend the out-of-the-box offering and will make decisions about this at a later date.
Read more

Not exactly.The embedded content element can be used to insert visualizations and content not supported out of the box. Further, there are many theme properties that can be controlled via dashboard-level settings. With that said, the Dashboards team is currently gathering requirements around how customers might like to extend the out-of-the-box offering and will make decisions about this at a later date.

patterns: Getting below error while trying to access data 'Error: Accessing data failed'
Unable to access data in ArcGIS Online
responses:
To resolve the issue, use one of the following options:
1. In ArcMap, create a local copy of the hosted feature layer, and edit the local copy to change the attribute values to blank spaces, or replace them with supported characters.
2. In ArcGIS Online, navigate to the item details page of the hosted feature layer, and click the Settings tab. In the Feature Layer (hosted) section, under What features can editors see?, select the Editors can see all features option.
Refer to ArcGIS Online: Manage editor settings for more information.
Read more

Refer to ArcGIS Online: Manage editor settings for more information.

patterns: Unable to view a web map in Collector for ArcGIS
Unable to view a web map in Collector for ArcGIS
responses:
This issue occurs due to one of the following causes:
The web map does not contain any editable feature services.
The feature service in the web map is published with grouped layers.The web map is configured as 'Exploratory' when published from ArcGIS Pro.The web map has not been enabled for use in Collector for ArcGIS.
Visit this page

This issue occurs due to one of the following causes:The web map does not contain any editable feature services. The feature service in the web map is published with grouped layers.The web map is configured as 'Exploratory' when published from ArcGIS Pro.The web map has not been enabled for use in Collector for ArcGIS. For more enquiry,
Visit this page

patterns: Downloading a web map for offline use with Collector for ArcGIS iOS or Android
Downloading a web map for offline use with Collector for ArcGIS iOS or Android
responses:
There are two options to work around this limitation:
Disable the option to move edits to base:-Stop the feature service that references the data.Unregister the feature class as versioned.
Register the feature class as versioned again, this time unchecking the option to move edits to base.Start the feature service.
Detailed documentation on using versioned data with offline editing work flows is available:
Offline maps and versioned data.
Choose instead to use non-versioned data with archiving enabled: Prepare data for offline use.
Know more

patterns: The containing process for 'System/PublishingToolsEx' job 'job_number' has crashed
Unable to publish a large number of records.
responses:
Publishing a large number of records causes the service to time out, as a large record service needs more time to be processed and published. This varies depending on the complexity of the services such as the number of layers or number of records.Â 
To resolve this issue, increase the maxUsageTime parameter to a higher value to allow the process to finish before the services time out from admin end point.
Read more

Publishing a large number of records causes the service to time out, as a large record service needs more time to be processed and published. This varies depending on the complexity of the services such as the number of layers or number of records.Â 
To resolve this issue, increase the maxUsageTime parameter to a higher value to allow the process to finish before the services time out from admin end point.
Read more

patterns: Unable to edit the geometry of a feature in an editable feature layer.
Unable to edit the geometry of a feature in an editable feature layer.
responses: If the editable feature layer contains m-values, you can't edit the geometry for existing features. To edit geometry for existing features in the layer, the layer owner must move the data with m-values to a separate layer (which can be in the same service).

If the editable feature layer contains m-values, you can't edit the geometry for existing features. To edit geometry for existing features in the layer, the layer owner must move the data with m-values to a separate layer (which can be in the same service).

4.Click Advanced.
5.The Advanced Configuration dialog box appears.

intents.tag: Transferring attachements from one sde to another gdb
patterns: Attachments are dropped when exporting a feature class from an enterprise geodatabase to a file geodatabase and vice versa
export tool dropping attachments
responses:
1.Copy and paste the feature class with attachments to the desired geodatabase. To transfer a feature class with attachments from a enterprise geodatabase (EGDB) to a file geodatabase (FGDB), follow the instructions provided below:Create a new feature dataset in the target FGDB using the spatial reference of one of the feature classes of the original enterprise geodatabase.
2. Copy the required feature classes and paste it to the newly created feature dataset in the FGDB. The attachments are successfully copied.

1.Copy and paste the feature class with attachments to the desired geodatabase. To transfer a feature class with attachments from a enterprise geodatabase (EGDB) to a file geodatabase (FGDB), follow the instructions provided below:Create a new feature dataset in the target FGDB using the spatial reference of one of the feature classes of the original enterprise geodatabase.
2. Copy the required feature classes and paste it to the newly created feature dataset in the FGDB. The attachments are successfully copied.

intents.tag: Unable to cerate default database database
patterns: Error: Unable to create or open the default database
Getting an error unable to create or open the default database
responses:
1.Ensure access to the default geodatabase is not prohibited by software such as firewalls or virtual private network (VPN) configurations. Esri recommends the default geodatabase be created on the local machine. To change the path to the new default geodatabase on the local machine, refer to How To: Set the default Home folder and geodatabase location for new map documents for more information.
2.In Windows Explorer, right-click the drive for the new default geodatabase, and select Properties.
3.Select the General tab, and ensure adequate space is available on the drive. The default file geodatabase requires no more than 0.5 MB.
4.In Windows Explorer, browse to the directory for the new default geodatabase.Right-click the folder, and select Properties
5.Select the Security tab, and ensure the user attempting to execute the software has Read and Write permissions.
6.If one or more Default.gdb folders exist in the workspace described in Step 4, delete them.
7.Rename the Default.gdb file to, rexample, Default_old.gdb. A new Default.gdb file is created when ArcMap loads.
8.Install the MSXML 4.0 Service Pack 3(Microsoft XML Core Services).
9.Run a software repair on ArcGIS Desktop.Refer to Repair or remove programs in Windows 10 for steps to do this.
10.Restart the machine, and launch ArcMap.The application starts successfully
Read more

1.Ensure access to the default geodatabase is not prohibited by software such as firewalls or virtual private network (VPN) configurations. Esri recommends the default geodatabase be created on the local machine. To change the path to the new default geodatabase on the local machine, refer to How To: Set the default Home folder and geodatabase location for new map documents for more information.
2.In Windows Explorer, right-click the drive for the new default geodatabase, and select Properties.
3.Select the General tab, and ensure adequate space is available on the drive. The default file geodatabase requires no more than 0.5 MB.
4.In Windows Explorer, browse to the directory for the new default geodatabase.Right-click the folder, and select Properties
5.Select the Security tab, and ensure the user attempting to execute the software has Read and Write permissions.
6.If one or more Default.gdb folders exist in the workspace described in Step 4, delete them.
7.Rename the Default.gdb file to, rexample, Default_old.gdb. A new Default.gdb file is created when ArcMap loads.
8.Install the MSXML 4.0 Service Pack 3(Microsoft XML Core Services).
9.Run a software repair on ArcGIS Desktop.Refer to Repair or remove programs in Windows 10 for steps to do this.
10.Restart the machine, and launch ArcMap.The application starts successfully
Read more

intents.tag: Failed to connect database Network I/O Error
patterns: Error: Failed to connect to database. Network I/O Error
Unable to connect database
responses:
1.Open Windows Explorer and navigate to the %SDEHOME% folder. Right-click on this 'SQLEXE' folder and select 'Properties'.2.Under the 'Security' tab select 'Add'. Type the name of the Windows user/group receiving permissions within this folder. On the bottom half of the sqlexe properties window, there is a series of check boxes for the amount of permissions the administrator wishes to grant to this user/group.Below illustrates where to 'Add' users/groups and the permissions needed.3.Now, Windows users should be able to use the correct connection parameters to successfully establish a connection to the database.
Read more

intents.tag: How to change the length of an existing field

How to change the length of an existing field
responses: We cannot increase the character length of an already existing text field. However,  a new text field with a length of 255 characters can be created and set the new field to mirror the properties of the original field.

We cannot increase the character length of an already existing text field. However,  a new text field with a length of 255 characters can be created and set the new field to mirror the properties of the original field.

responses:
1.Go to SQL Server Managemnet studio.
2.Refresh SQL Server instance.
3. Go to ArcMap>Database connection>Make a new database connection>Disconnect old connection.

1.Go to SQL Server Managemnet studio.
2.Refresh SQL Server instance.
3. Go to ArcMap>Database connection>Make a new database connection>Disconnect old connection.

intents.tag: Error 002118 Operation not supported on a table
patterns: Error 002118
Error 002118: Operation not supported on a table that has archiving enabled
Getting warning 002118
responses:
Certain datasets that have archiving enabled cannot be registered or unregistered as versioned without first disabling archiving. The correct order of operations must be followed.First, disable archiving on the dataset. Then, complete the unregister or register as versioned operation. Note that the archiving history will be lost when you disable archiving.
Read more

Certain datasets that have archiving enabled cannot be registered or unregistered as versioned without first disabling archiving. The correct order of operations must be followed.First, disable archiving on the dataset. Then, complete the unregister or register as versioned operation. Note that the archiving history will be lost when you disable archiving.
Read more

intents.tag: with the option to register existing data only
patterns: Issue with edits from one of the feature class participating in the replica not bring the changes over to the child geodatabase even after successful synchronization
Unable to edits from one of the feature class participating in the replica
responses:
1.Delete the problematic feature dataset and the related tables from the child (published) geodatabase.
2.Reconcile, post and compress both the child and parent geodatabase during the afterhours Unregister the replica from both the geodatabases
3.Copy and paste the feature dataset from the production (Parent) geodatabase. It will bring the related tables as well.
4.finally recreate the replica with the option to register existing data only.

1.Delete the problematic feature dataset and the related tables from the child (published) geodatabase.
2.Reconcile, post and compress both the child and parent geodatabase during the afterhours Unregister the replica from both the geodatabases
3.Copy and paste the feature dataset from the production (Parent) geodatabase. It will bring the related tables as well.
4.finally recreate the replica with the option to register existing data only.

intents.tag: enable/disable admin access for the ArcGIS Server web adaptor
patterns: Issue: How to enable/disable admin access for the ArcGIS Server web adaptor without reconfiguring the web adaptor
Steps to enable/disable admin access for the ArcGIS Server web adaptor without reconfiguring the web adaptor
responses:
1.Sign into the admin endpoint of ArcGIS Server.
2. Navigate to system > web adaptor.
3.Select the link that corresponds to the web adaptor you wish to change (it may take some guess work as they are labeled with a hash code rather than the name)
4. In the URL box of the browser, add /update
5. You can then check/uncheck the box for Administrative access

1.Sign into the admin endpoint of ArcGIS Server.
2. Navigate to system > web adaptor.
3.Select the link that corresponds to the web adaptor you wish to change (it may take some guess work as they are labeled with a hash code rather than the name)
4. In the URL box of the browser, add /update
5. You can then check/uncheck the box for Administrative access

patterns: Error: Failed to connect to database. No ArcGIS Server license found. Contact your geodatabase administrator to update license
Unable to upgrade an enterprise geodatabase license
responses:
1.Open a new session in ArcGIS Pro and connect to the Geodatabase you want to upgrade the license from Catalog pane.
2.Search for the tool Update Enterprise Geodatabase License (Data Management) from Geoprocessing tools.
3.-Provide the input as the database connection (.sde) for which we want to update the license.
4.For Authorization file put in the new keycodes file that was generated with the new ECP number from My ESRI portal.
5.-Run the tool. This should update the license for the current Enterprise Geodatabase.
6.-Open a new session of Pro and check if the license is updated.
7.Additionally check in the SDE_server_config repository table for the new ECP Number
Read more

patterns: Problem: Unable to compress a geodatabase in ArcGIS for Server
Unable to compress a geodatabase in ArcGIS for Server
responses:
Use the Rebuild Indexes tool to resolve this issue. The Rebuild Indexes tool re-creates the indexes and updates the database statistics for the tables in the .db. To locate the Rebuild Indexes tool, navigate to ArcCatalog > Toolboxes > SystemToolboxes > Data Management Tools > Geodatabase Administration > Rebuild Indexes.
Visit here

Use the Rebuild Indexes tool to resolve this issue. The Rebuild Indexes tool re-creates the indexes and updates the database statistics for the tables in the .db. intents.tag: Failed to Compress the database - ERROR 999999
patterns: Failed to Compress the database - ERROR 999999
Encountering an error 999999 while compressing a database
responses:
The error refered to an orphaned locks present in the locks tables of the geodatabase. Check all the locks tables from the backend respectively and clear them one by one.
Read more

The error refered to an orphaned locks present in the locks tables of the geodatabase. Check all the locks tables from the backend respectively and clear them one by one.

patterns: Error: The connection property set was missing a required property or the property value was unrecognized
Unable to create a datastore
responses:
Depending on the cause, choose one of the workarounds below to resolve.The ArcGIS Server Windows service does not have read permissions. Install the Microsoft ODBC driver on the client machine 1.Log in to My Esri.
2.Navigate to My Organizations > Downloads > Products. Search for ArcGIS Enterprise (Windows), select the version from the Version drop-down list, and click View Downloads.
3.In the Download Components pane, expand Database Support Files, and search for the appropriate Microsoft ODBC driver. Click Download.
4.Run the Microsoft ODBC driver installer to install the driver.
5.The SDE file can now be used to create a data store.
Read more

Depending on the cause, choose one of the workarounds below to resolve.The ArcGIS Server Windows service does not have read permissions. Install the Microsoft ODBC driver on the client machine 1.Log in to My Esri.
2.Navigate to My Organizations > Downloads > Products. Search for ArcGIS Enterprise (Windows), select the version from the Version drop-down list, and click View Downloads.
3.In the Download Components pane, expand Database Support Files, and search for the appropriate Microsoft ODBC driver. Click Download.
4.Run the Microsoft ODBC driver installer to install the driver.
5.The SDE file can now be used to create a data store.
Read more

intents.tag: capture traffic being sent to ArcGIS Server through the Web Adaptor
patterns: How to capture traffic being sent to ArcGIS Server through the Web Adaptor
Steps to capture traffic being sent to ArcGIS Server through the Web Adaptor
responses:
1. Open IIS Manager expand the IIS Instance, and select Application Pools.
2. R-click ArcGISWebAdaptorAppPool v4.0 Advanced Settings
3. Select Identity (under Process Model). Click the ellipses next to the username ApplicationPoolIdentity
4. In the Application Pool Identity dialog, choose Custom Account and click Set.
5. Enter your username (that you're signed into the machine as), in the format domain user, and enter the domain user password twice.
6. Open Fiddler, and submit a request to ArcGIS Server through REST using the Web Adaptor (from a different machine). Fiddler will capture the request being submitted to ArcGIS Server

1. Open IIS Manager expand the IIS Instance, and select Application Pools.
2. R-click ArcGISWebAdaptorAppPool v4.0 Advanced Settings
3. Select Identity (under Process Model). Click the ellipses next to the username ApplicationPoolIdentity
4. In the Application Pool Identity dialog, choose Custom Account and click Set.
5. Enter your username (that you're signed into the machine as), in the format domain user, and enter the domain user password twice.
6. Open Fiddler, and submit a request to ArcGIS Server through REST using the Web Adaptor (from a different machine). Fiddler will capture the request being submitted to ArcGIS Server

patterns: What is log4shell
How does log4shell affect ArcGIS Enterprise
responses:
Esri is actively investigating the impact of the Log4j library vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228) disclosed on December 9, 2021, as some Esri products contain this common logging tool. This bulletin contains the latest information about Esri products and will be updated as new information becomes available. Log4Shell is imapcting 10.7.1 and below.
Please refer this

patterns: What is log4shell solution
How does log4shell can be resolved
log4shell solution
responses: ESRI has come out with scripts that will remove the parts of log4j that is exploitable. This can be done without needing to upgrade our versions. The instructions for Portal, ArcGIS Server and Data Store are located here
